17   | /**
18   |  * Interface to YAJL's JSON stream parsing facilities.
19   |  **/
20   | 
21   | #include <yajl/yajl_common.h>
22   | 
23   | #ifndef __YAJL_PARSE_H__
24   | #define __YAJL_PARSE_H__
25   | 
26   | #include <stddef.h>
27   | 
28   | #ifdef __cplusplus
29   | extern "C" {
30   | #endif
31   |     /*+ error codes returned from this interface +*/
32   |     typedef enum {
33   |         /*+ no error was encountered +*/
34   |         yajl_status_ok,
35   |         /*+ a client callback returned zero, stopping the parse +*/
36   |         yajl_status_client_canceled,
37   |         /*+ An error occurred during the parse.  Call yajl_get_error for
38   |          *  more information about the encountered error +*/
39   |         yajl_status_error
40   |     } yajl_status;
41   | 
42   |     /*+ attain a human readable, english, string for an error +*/
43   |     YAJL_API const char * yajl_status_to_string(yajl_status code);
44   | 
45   |     /*+ an opaque handle to a parser +*/
46   |     typedef struct yajl_handle_t * yajl_handle;
47   | 
48   |     /*+ yajl is an event driven parser.  this means as json elements are
49   |      *  parsed, you are called back to do something with the data.  The
50   |      *  functions in this table indicate the various events for which
51   |      *  you will be called back.  Each callback accepts a "context"
52   |      *  pointer, this is a void * that is passed into the yajl_parse
53   |      *  function which the client code may use to pass around context.
54   |      *
55   |      *  All callbacks return an integer.  If non-zero, the parse will
56   |      *  continue.  If zero, the parse will be canceled and
57   |      *  yajl_status_client_canceled will be returned from the parse.
58   |      *
59   |      *  \attention {
60   |      *    A note about the handling of numbers:
61   |      *
62   |      *    yajl will only convert numbers that can be represented in a
63   |      *    double or a 64 bit (long long) int.  All other numbers will
64   |      *    be passed to the client in string form using the yajl_number
65   |      *    callback.  Furthermore, if yajl_number is not NULL, it will
66   |      *    always be used to return numbers, that is yajl_integer and
67   |      *    yajl_double will be ignored.  If yajl_number is NULL but one
68   |      *    of yajl_integer or yajl_double are defined, parsing of a
69   |      *    number larger than is representable in a double or 64 bit
70   |      *    integer will result in a parse error.
71   |      *  }
72   |      +*/
73   |     typedef struct {
74   |         int (* yajl_null)(void * ctx);
75   |         int (* yajl_boolean)(void * ctx, int boolVal);
76   |         int (* yajl_integer)(void * ctx, long long integerVal);
77   |         int (* yajl_double)(void * ctx, double doubleVal);
78   |         /*+ A callback which passes the string representation of the number
79   |          *  back to the client.  Will be used for all numbers when present +*/
80   |         int (* yajl_number)(void * ctx, const char * numberVal,
81   |                             size_t numberLen);
82   | 
83   |         /*+ strings are returned as pointers into the JSON text when,
84   |          * possible, as a result, they are _not_ null padded +*/
85   |         int (* yajl_string)(void * ctx, const unsigned char * stringVal,
86   |                             size_t stringLen);
87   | 
88   |         int (* yajl_start_map)(void * ctx);
89   |         int (* yajl_map_key)(void * ctx, const unsigned char * key,
90   |                              size_t stringLen);
91   |         int (* yajl_end_map)(void * ctx);
92   | 
93   |         int (* yajl_start_array)(void * ctx);
94   |         int (* yajl_end_array)(void * ctx);
95   |     } yajl_callbacks;
96   | 
97   |     YAJL_API yajl_handle yajl_alloc(const yajl_callbacks * callbacks,
98   |                                     yajl_alloc_funcs * afs,
99   |                                     void * ctx);
100  | 
101  | 
102  |     /*+ configuration parameters for the parser, these may be passed to
103  |      *  yajl_config() along with option specific argument(s).  In general,
104  |      *  all configuration parameters default to *off*. +*/
105  |     typedef enum {
106  |         /*+ Ignore javascript style comments present in
107  |          *  JSON input.  Non-standard, but rather fun
108  |          *  arguments: toggled off with integer zero, on otherwise.
109  |          *
110  |          *  example:
111  |          *    yajl_config(h, yajl_allow_comments, 1); // turn comment support on
112  |          +*/
113  |         yajl_allow_comments            = (1 << 0),
114  |         /*+
115  |          * When set the parser will verify that all strings in JSON input are
116  |          * valid UTF8 and will emit a parse error if this is not so.  When set,
117  |          * this option makes parsing slightly more expensive (~7% depending
118  |          * on processor and compiler in use)
119  |          *
120  |          * example:
121  |          *   yajl_config(h, yajl_dont_validate_strings, 1); // disable utf8 checking
122  |          +*/
123  |         yajl_dont_validate_strings     = (1 << 1),
124  |         /*+
125  |          * By default, upon calls to yajl_complete_parse(), yajl will
126  |          * ensure the entire input text was consumed and will raise an error
127  |          * otherwise.  Enabling this flag will cause yajl to disable this
128  |          * check.  This can be useful when parsing json out of a that contains more
129  |          * than a single JSON document.
130  |          +*/
131  |         yajl_allow_trailing_garbage    = (1 << 2),
132  |         /*+
133  |          * Allow multiple values to be parsed by a single handle.  The
134  |          * entire text must be valid JSON, and values can be seperated
135  |          * by any kind of whitespace.  This flag will change the
136  |          * behavior of the parser, and cause it continue parsing after
137  |          * a value is parsed, rather than transitioning into a
138  |          * complete state.  This option can be useful when parsing multiple
139  |          * values from an input stream.
140  |          +*/
141  |         yajl_allow_multiple_values     = (1 << 3),
142  |         /*+
143  |          * When yajl_complete_parse() is called the parser will
144  |          * check that the top level value was completely consumed.  I.E.,
145  |          * if called whilst in the middle of parsing a value
146  |          * yajl will enter an error state (premature EOF).  Setting this
147  |          * flag suppresses that check and the corresponding error.
148  |          +*/
149  |         yajl_allow_partial_values      = (1 << 4)
150  |     } yajl_option;
151  | 
152  |     YAJL_API int yajl_config(yajl_handle h, yajl_option opt, ...);
153  |     YAJL_API void yajl_free(yajl_handle handle);
154  |     YAJL_API yajl_status yajl_parse(yajl_handle hand,
155  |                                     const unsigned char * jsonText,
156  |                                     size_t jsonTextLength);
157  |     YAJL_API yajl_status yajl_complete_parse(yajl_handle hand);
158  |     YAJL_API unsigned char * yajl_get_error(yajl_handle hand, int verbose,
159  |                                             const unsigned char * jsonText,
160  |                                             size_t jsonTextLength);
161  |     YAJL_API size_t yajl_get_bytes_consumed(yajl_handle hand);
162  |     YAJL_API void yajl_free_error(yajl_handle hand, unsigned char * str);
163  | 
164  | #ifdef __cplusplus
165  | }
166  | #endif
167  | 
168  | #endif
